title: Collage Dance Collective grows by leaps and bounds
text:
BINGHAMPTON, Tenn. (AP) - As Collage Dance Collective celebrates its 10th anniversary season this fall, executive director Marcellus Harper is amazed by the ballet company’s success, and hopes to accomplish more in the coming years.

“It reminds us how young the organization is, too,” Harper said. “There’s a lot that we still want to do and see necessary to do, and we’re excited about this next chapter.”

Collage, located in the Broad Avenue Arts District in Binghampton, is launching its 10th anniversary season with its fall program ballet performance from Oct. 25-27 at Germantown Performing Arts Center.

Collage was founded in New York in 2006, and relocated to Memphis in 2007 as the company’s leadership was attracted to the city’s growing arts movement.

The company started with one student at a Memphis church, and used several church spaces over its first few years in Memphis. Collage launched its first professional ballet season in 2009 and settled into its current home at 2497 Broad Ave. in 2012.

“We’ve played an integral part in the revitalization that’s happened on Broad Avenue,” Harper said. “Lots of folks in the district were really working to center arts and creative makers and using that energy to spur economic development. That’s always resonated with us.”

Collage now serves nearly 500 students a week and has eight professional dancers who tour nationally and internationally. Students, from ages 2 to high school, and dancers perform both classical and contemporary ballet.

“I don’t think we could’ve predicted it,” Harper said about the company’s success. “We’ve always had the vision, but it’s hard sometimes, particularly when you have a vision that seems too massive to predict how you’re going to get there.”

Rickey Flagg II is entering his fifth year with Collage’s professional performance group. Originally from Connecticut, Flagg said Collage’s family-like atmosphere has helped him in his craft, as opposed to prior companies he performed for where there was a more “malicious” atmosphere.

“It was the first time I was able to open my eyes to being something bigger to myself,” Flagg said of Collage.

Collage needs to continue inspiring students, he said, particularly those of color, and exposing others who are not as familiar with their work to the arts. Flagg also pointed to the company’s diversity as another reason for its growing success.

“We have people from different parts of the world,” Flagg said. “Especially in the South, it’s not a frequent practice I’ll say.”

Luisa Cardoso auditioned for Collage several years ago in Miami when she was wrapping up her time at Miami City Ballet School. Several successful auditions later, Cardoso, who is from Brazil, is now entering her fourth season with Collage.

Cardoso said it took a while to adjust to the slower pace of Memphis compared to Miami and her hometown of Salvador, Brazil, which has a population of nearly 3 million people. Collage’s engagement with its students and the community at large really impressed her.

“I hope that people want to come to Memphis and make Memphis (their) home,” Cardoso said.

Growing the number of national and international students and tripling the number of students served are two of Harper’s goals for the next three to five years. Collage also hopes to build new offices and performance space at 501 Tillman St. to accommodate its growth.

“We have to continue the work so we can make this even larger,” Harper said.
